awd_titl_txt: CPS: Small: Energy-Aware Formal Synthesis for Supervisory Control and Information Acquisition in Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is developing theoretical foundations and computational algorithms for synthesizing higher-level supervisory and information-acquisition control logic in cyber-physical systems that expend or replenish their resources while interacting with the environment. On the one hand, qualitative requirements capture the safety requirements that are imposed on the system as it operates. On the other hand, quantitative requirements capture resource constraints in the context of energy-aware systems. These dual considerations are needed in applications of cyber-physical systems where efficient management of resources must be accounted for in the dynamic operation of the system in order to achieve the desired objectives within a given energy or resource budget.

The approach pursued is formal and model-based. It leverages a recently-developed unified framework for supervisory control and information acquisition in the higher-level control logic of cyber-physical systems, but it explicitly embeds quantitative constraints in the solution procedure in order to capture the energy or resources expended and/or replenished by the cyber-physical system as it interacts with its environment. This generic solution methodology is applicable to several classes of cyber-physical systems subject to energy constraints. Software tools are being developed to facilitate the transition of these results to application domains. Of special interest is energy-aware mission planning in autonomous systems, a rich domain where qualitative mission requirements are coupled with quantitative constraints. Overall, this project impacts both the Science of Cyber-Physical Systems and the Engineering of Cyber-Physical Systems.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed theoretical foundations and computational algorithms for synthesizing higher-level supervisory and information acquisition-release control logic in cyber-physical systems that expend or replenish their resources while interacting with the environment. On the one hand, qualitative requirements capture the safety requirements that are imposed on the system as it operates. On the other hand, quantitative requirements capture resource constraints in the context of energy-aware systems. These dual considerations are needed in applications of cyber-physical systems where efficient management of resources must be accounted for in the dynamic operation of the system in order to achieve the desired objectives within a given energy or resource budget.

The approach pursued was formal and model-based. It is based on a unified framework for supervisory control and information management at the higher-level control logic of cyber-physical systems, where quantitative constraints are explicitly embedded in the solution procedure in order to capture the energy or resources expended and/or replenished by the cyber-physical system as it interacts with its environment. This generic solution methodology is applicable to several classes of cyber-physical systems subject to resource constraints. 

We considered two classes of problems. (i) Supervisory control, which refers to the synthesis of the higher-level control logic. In this context, the logical specifications pertain to the safety and liveness requirements imposed on the system while the quantitative constraints pertain to energy or other limited resources in the operation of the system. (ii) Privacy enforcement by obfuscation, where information is communicated over a public channel and an eavesdropper may intercept information that should remain private. In this class of problems, the logical specifications pertain to different forms of privacy, modeled using the formal notion of opacity, and the quantitative constraints pertain to both the capabilities of the obfuscating mechanism (based on editing the information output by the system) as well as the utility of the obfuscated information to legitimate recipients. Our investigations in (ii) were conducted in collaboration with a colleague at Michigan Robotics. In both classes of problems, in order to achieve greater scalability, we investigated different classes of system abstractions termed stutter bisimulation, opaque bisimulation, and opaque observation equivalence; the latter two are new concepts developed in this project. Moreover, in the context of supervisory control, we also investigated deception attacks on sensor and actuators that aim to degrade system performance by steering it to an unsafe state. We looked into how such attacks could be deployed by a malicious entity when some sensors and actuators in the feedback loop become compromised, and how the supervisory control logic could be made resilient to such attacks.

The research conducted in this project resulted in formal methodologies and associated software tools that will have a significant impact on the performance, security, and privacy of a large class of technological systems that are of great societal importance.  Results were published in archival journals and conference proceedings. Software tools implementing the methodologies that were developed are publicly available from the project website maintained at the University of Michigan. This project contributed to the training of several graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and undergraduate students at the University of Michigan in the important area of feedback control of cyber-physical systems.
